data.text: Carbon Frames for Bikepacking?

Hi All, I am in a unique position that I might be able to spend more than planned on a new bike. Question: are carbon frames worth it? I am looking at a Treck Checkpoint SL5 and a Canyon Inlifte. Thanks for the feedback!

Well that all depends, Im biased so I dislike carbon. If youre willing to dish out cash, go for Ti. But what are you wanting out of a bike? Personally Carbon is too fragile, id snap it just sitting on it so I know carbon isnt for me.
data.author: James Cupp

data.text: I am looking for something that can fit 45-622 tires. Take a second set of wheels for the road. The occasional “rougher” gravel is a possibility as well as forest trails
data.author: Filip Rabuzin

data.text: fragile?
data.author: Dustin Bise

data.text: I race CX, Im not above taking a road bike to do slope style. Im very aggressive and assertive, I only ride steel.
data.author: James Cupp

data.text: Carbon today is often stiffer than frames a few years ago so you wont have much flex. Flex id bad. Back when I was still selling new bikes, around 2014, you can push the bottom bracket several inches over with your foot. Sure its lightwight, but youre losing so much power from your drive train cause its all being delivered incorrectly. In this respecy alloy was superior as it was very rigid. If you get a good deal on a carbon gravel, jump on it. Otherwise, invest in an alloy bike and upgrade your drive train, wheels and tires. Or .. buy ti, but ti is NOT cheap. I hope this helps you in some way.
data.author: James Cupp

data.text: do you enjoy kool-aid?
data.author: Dustin Bise

data.text: thanks! I will look into that. I have a Cube Nuroad at the moment with Tiagra and OEM wheels. I can get DT Swiss readonably affordably, but with the drivetrains being expensive and not so available, I was thinking to sell and buy a second hand specced out bike
data.author: Filip Rabuzin

data.text: "you can push the bottom bracket several inches over with your foot." what???
data.author: Dustin Bise

data.text: I do actually. And you?
data.author: James Cupp

data.text: Ah, so you never knew that carbon flexes. Look it up, its very interesting. Unlike most reps that read the back of the card to sell bikes, I actually paid attention to the RnD and history of cycling. Older carbon frames used to flex so much thst it was terrifying, when youre pedaling most of your power is shifting the frame side to side and not delivering power to the ground. Theyve gotten better with how they lay up the carbon now, but a few years ago the only benefit to carbon was it was light, thats it.
data.author: James Cupp

data.text:
watch this video and look at the back wheel compared to the seat post tube. https://youtu.be/cAz5wOBxuMI
Carbon Fibre Road Bike Flex
youtube.com
data.author: James Cupp

data.text: was a long time ago (in bike years)... steel was worse, and I've had plenty of alloy frames that were just as bad. My 2005 Tarmac was fairly stiff, stiffer than any alloy bike I'd ridden previous to it. My 2015 Giant Propel was extremely stiff. My 2018 Allez Sprint (alloy) was extremely stiff for an alloy bike. More stiff than the 2005 Tarmac, but probably less than the Propel (but it was close). My 2020 Aspero (carbon gravel) may as well be an steel I-Beam. There is NO flex in the bottom bracket, but it's still comfortable enough that I occasionally ride it on MTB trails.
data.author: Drew Downing

data.text: Vincent Wheels How many trees have you hit without damaging the frame?
data.author: James Cupp

data.text: I have an Aluminum Checkpoint, my co-worker has a carbon Checkpoint. Same tires We've ridden back to back. No real difference in ride quality. Better wheels on his bike are noticeable. His 1X sucks ass compared to my 2X as you frequently feel like you're a gear off. Brakes are both relatively similar feeling. His levers feel better. Neither one of us can tell the difference in weight or frame under way.
data.author: Mikey Mutz

data.text: thanks for this! I was definitely thinking of getting something with DT Swiss G1800 wheels
data.author: Filip Rabuzin

data.text: A big part of carbon is the ride. Take the bike for a spin and see how you like it on long flats, sprinting, and grinding up a hill. A good designer will use the right material for the bike’s intended use. Edited for grammar.
data.author: Bill Bulek

data.text:
Carbon is incredibly durable, especially modern frames, and I’ve never had issues with several bikes over the last couple decades. If you can afford Titanium, I think that would be best, but carbon frames are great. https://youtu.be/w5eMMf11uhM
Carbon vs Aluminum Frames - Which is Stronger?
youtube.com
data.author: Erick Alexander Betancourt

data.text: please dont use this as an example of carbons strength. while the video is impressive, these frames are likely having massive delamination on the first couple strikes, despite there being no visual damage. its not a good representation of what makes carbon good, or how "strong" it is. there is lots of misguided information in this thread today.
data.author: Dustin Bise

data.text: Get the best bike you can afford That being said if it’s not a huge diff I think for gravel carbon is worth it as the vibration level is prob less I just got an SL5 over an aluminum Didn’t want to spend the extra 1200 but I am glad I did It’s a great bike But again ride what you can be comfortable with and enjoy
data.author: Larry Shapiro

data.text: I have a revolt 0, alloy bike and I can feel the bumpy road and every details along the ride. Tubeless tires does help but I am using tube now. I rode an Orbea TERRA m20 before and the ride quality is much better. I went over cracks and bumps and I don't feel any vibration. I am looking to upgrade now but one issue is I use my gravel bike for road, gravel and trainer. Alloy is better option for trainer. In additional, same groupset but different frame cost almost double with very small advantage. You could say carbon is lighter and it will help the climbing too. Another option is get a carbon wheel instead. That's what I am going to try first.
data.author: Edward Lo

data.text: Interesting that you rate Alloy for the indoor trainer. I took insufficient care with mine and the sweat wrecked the frame.
data.author: John Knapp

data.text: yeah usually I used trainer between late Nov to mid April. That's actually 5 months of the season. Ideally is good to have 2 bikes but not everyone wants to spend money to maintain 2 bikes.
data.author: Edward Lo

data.text: I own 13. I ride them all regularly 2.
data.author: James Cupp

data.text: lol sure everyone is different
data.author: Edward Lo

data.text: I used to be a courier, so I never had an off season. Blizzard? Better pull out my cross bike.
data.author: James Cupp

data.text: I get that. It was my winter trainer that didn’t owe me a thing by the time the frame got too corroded to trust it outdoors. But after a couple of Al bikes that ended up too corroded to trust I’d not get another. I’m very lucky and have both Ti and C these days. They both have things to commend them.
data.author: John Knapp

data.text: I actually want a carbon too. The ride is just much more comfortable. I am thinking either an endurance or gravel bike.
data.author: Edward Lo

data.text: I'd get the carbon if you can afford it it is noticeable over Aluminum. People hate on carbon for no reason. There is a reason fighter jets and formula 1 cars are made out of carbon fiber.
data.author: Cameron Swauger

data.text: I can admit im biased, but its not for no reason. Lol I just like what I like.
data.author: James Cupp

data.text: Ti is also awesome. If you do go aluminum I’ve heard that the Salsa Warbird design is great and similar feel of carbon
data.author: Doug Hanna

data.text: warbirds are carbon now I have one!
data.author: Art Pelham

data.text: I would go di2 before carbon.
data.author: Rich Wachtel

data.text: really? What is the main reason?
data.author: Filip Rabuzin

data.text: For me it’s perfect shifts every time, and having remote buttons.
data.author: Rich Wachtel

data.text: , and no snapped cables buried in your shifters. And no need for adjustment once it’s set. 👍🏼
data.author: Ryan Hall

data.text: Once I went carbon I never went back. It makes an enormous difference in weight and controlling vibration
data.author: Katherine Alley

data.text: Carbon bikes would usually be more compliant. Manufacturers can manipulate the weave and layup to give more or less compliance. You won’t feel the difference on a short ride, but you will after longer rides in the saddle. Both alu and carbon are usually offered with lifetime warranty on frame, plus crash replacements.
data.author: Andrew Waung

data.text: I think the caveat is “all else being equal”. By that I mean, the way you and the bike fit together often has a greater influence over your enjoyment of the bike than most other factors. I won’t say where you should spend your money (although I’m full of researched and experienced opinions) but I will say that I repair carbon every day and it is a fantastic material from which to make a frame.
data.author: Ryan Hall

data.text: I’ve heard it’s easier to repair carbon over aluminum.
data.author: Andrew Waung

data.text: , I would say that, but then I am biased. I can’t weld aluminum, but I can manipulate composites. I’m sure an aluminum expert might say the opposite. But, of the 5 bikes on the proverbial bench today, I’d venture to guess that, if they were aluminum, 3 would be tossed, one would be waiting for (praying for) a rear triangle, and one would be ignored and ridden (potentially at its peril). In my eyes, it’s repairability is part of what makes it a great material to use for bikes. Now, to add clarity, the fact that these are here being repaired shouldn’t be misconstrued as the material being weak. Only one of them was crash damage (that would have left an alloy frame in the same state) and the rest were either car rack damage, transit or shipping damage, and bike stand damage. So, I have full confidence in the material (as long as construction was executed properly, which is true of all materials).
data.author: Ryan Hall

data.text: Why not a steel cro-mo frame? Supple ride, strong, guaranteed a lifetime. Or if as you say, extra money, a titanium frame? I am riding a steel Kona Rove LTD with 27.5 wheels, 650b x47 tires and love it. Mine has two front rings as it can double as a touring bike too.
data.author: Todd McKinnon

data.text: I love that Trek. I would add a 27.5 wheelset and be in heaven. If you don't bikepack or box your bike up and travel a ton, Carbon is only topped by titanium
data.author: Alex Helling

data.text: Vincent Wheels a bicycle is a tool that can be used in many ways. The way I use bicycles most frequently use mean carbon is not a frame material I would chose. It definitely has its place in the market but it's just not my flavor.

data.text: I have the carbon checkpoint - it is amazing - comfortable - fast - light - but strong enough to carry shit.

data.text: snobbery? 🤣 I think not. I've owned both brand's, and never will again. They were junk that were more to maintain than enjoy. Then, the bike "local" shop, advised me of the manufacturing of and where of the brands. 🤔🤔.... That's why I prefer Amarican made. 🍻

data.text: Carbon frames are pretty fun and I love the speed I get out of mine. Can't help on personal experience on the two models you suggested, but I own Bianchi and BH and both have been absolutely fantastic performers
data.author: Thomas M Leaidicker

data.text: Carbon is great, just please wrap that new bike with helicopter tape... Also remember it does not like to be very hot.. Think car exhaust, and carbon rims on rear racks. I went back to AL on the Mtn bike, very bombproof, just don't ask how much it wghs...
data.author: Justin Pare

data.text: more mass means more assistance from gravity so you bomb hills faster. Why leave a wake when you can leave a crater?
data.author: James Cupp

data.text: Trek carbon is good stuff.
data.author: Dave Hunt

data.text: I went back to steel .
data.author: Kevin Dean

data.text: I never left steel.
data.author: James Cupp

data.text: Those arnt the same bike. One is a gravel bike and the other is a cross bike. Not sure if you know that. They are very similar but a more accurate comparison would be Checkpoint vs Grail (gravel) or Boone vs Inflite (cross).
data.author: Kyle Couture

data.text: thanks, I did look at that and came to this realisation. I was looking at second hand. Maybe Grail or Grizl from Canyon?
data.author: Filip Rabuzin

data.text: the grizl is a more heavy duty work horse bike. The grail or checkpoint can handle anything you intend to use it for im sure. The grizl has more mounts for bags and is good for long bikepacking type stuff where you will be tackling some serious terrain.
data.author: Kyle Couture

data.text: If you can afford Ti I would buy it. Likely last frame you’ll ever buy.
data.author: Mark Gunkel

data.text: The difference between carbon and aluminum frames is night and day. Carbon dampens small bumps and is a much nicer ride. I personally have owned steel and while it rides nicely I just don’t feel it is worth the weight penalty. (All that said my next bike will most likely be titanium.)
data.author: Jason Geer

data.text: All 3 of my gravel/bikepacking rigs are carbon. Ti is a pretty sweet option too.
data.author: Justin M Short BA
Tom Edwards

data.text: Go Trek Checkpoint!

data.text: So, update, a Checkpoint SL7 was offered to me for a reasonable price. What is everyone’s stance on SRAM eTap?
data.author: Filip Rabuzin

data.text: Instead of replacing cables and housings, you need to make sure the batteries are charged and good to go. Its still maint either way, but Id tend to steer away from it. Like electric cars, what if theres no charging port nearby? But I have no real opinion either way, as long as it works and is responsive, should do fine.
